content.raw:
The tests are build by default. Just in case, make sure to turn the following flag for cmake:

`cmake .. -DENABLE_TESTS_COMPILATION=True`

Running `make test` would run all of the tests in Gazebo, which takes a long time. To run just the `ModelAlign` test for example you can just:

~~~
cd build/gazebo/gui/
./UNIT_ModelAlign_TEST
~~~
content.html:
The tests are build by default. Just in case, make sure to turn the following flag for cmake:

cmake .. -DENABLE_TESTS_COMPILATION=True

Running make test would run all of the tests in Gazebo, which takes a long time. To run just the ModelAlign test for example you can just:

cd build/gazebo/gui/
./UNIT_ModelAlign_TEST

content.raw: Yes, you're correct, there's no unit test for the class yet. That's something we're trying to fix as we add new functionality to Gazebo. Let me know if you need help creating a test. I would start by copying the `ModelAlign_TEST`, for example. The `SetHighlighted` test is probably similar to what we need here.
content.html: Yes, you're correct, there's no unit test for the class yet. That's something we're trying to fix as we add new functionality to Gazebo. Let me know if you need help creating a test. I would start by copying the ModelAlign_TEST, for example. The SetHighlighted test is probably similar to what we need here.

pull_request.title: Model becomes transparent while being manpulated

pullrequest.title: Model becomes transparent while being manpulated

content.raw:
Thank you for the contribution! We will be reviewing this shortly. 

One thing I noticed already though is that this might change the original transparency of models which weren't fully opaque in the first place. 
The part which sets the model to be semi-transparent seems to be the same as the logic used in [ModelAlign](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/80a47d8eb0ea7cd8b09b951670e765b91c80273e/gazebo/gui/ModelAlign.cc?fileviewer=file-view-default#ModelAlign.cc-357), but the part making it opaque again should probably be something like `std::abs(_vis->GetTransparency()*2.0-1.0)` instead of zero.

Another suggestion is to add a unit test for the new functionality.
content.html:
Thank you for the contribution! We will be reviewing this shortly.

One thing I noticed already though is that this might change the original transparency of models which weren't fully opaque in the first place. The part which sets the model to be semi-transparent seems to be the same as the logic used in ModelAlign, but the part making it opaque again should probably be something like std::abs(_vis->GetTransparency()*2.0-1.0) instead of zero.

Another suggestion is to add a unit test for the new functionality.
